ellenosborne.monologue: Yes, I have a resolution. So whereas this past year, in the words of our state of the division report has been a year like any other filled with challenges and opportunities not easily imagined in February of 2020. And whereas the events and decisions of the past year have made the business of our school board, more complicated and consequential for the health of our students and staff into their academic, social and emotional well being. And whereas during this highly volatile Tom the board's connection to students, staff and families became even stronger as the number of opinions and insight offered to the board through emails and messages multiplied as much as 100 fold. as the number of participants at board meetings increased to thousands, as public comment was made more accessible, significantly increasing the number of speakers able to interact with board members, and whereas the transition from in-person to virtual meetings continues to present unplanned management duties, the fulfillment of which are crucial to the effective and responsive functioning of the board, And whereas during this period of time, one constant has been Ms. Jennifer Johnston, who this year was appointed for the 20th consecutive year to serve as a clerk of the board. And whereas Ms. Johnston has performed the new requirements presented by the pandemic while executing the board's priority to expand community engagement, and while also fulfilling her already considerable legal duties as board clerk. And whereas each year, Virginia School Board Association designates one week in February to build awareness of the role board clerks play in assisting school board members, superintendents, and our local schools. And whereas the association reminds us of how especially important this constant awareness is this year when Mrs. Johnston has been so instrumental to our success as we have managed through the barrage of changes resulting from the pandemic. Now therefore be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board publicly expresses its deepest appreciation to Ms. Jennifer Johnston for her exceptional service and support of our work and therefore of the thousands of student and staff members we serve. And we call upon all constituents to join with us in recognizing Ms. Johnston's invaluable contributions to public education in Albemarle County and to join us in thanking her for two decades of outstanding service as the clerk of the Albemarle County School Board. Thank you.

ellenosborne.monologue: Yes, thank you. So we have a resolution. I'm going to read it now. It's in regard to the Child Nutrition Services. Whereas on Friday, March 13, Virginia Governor Ralph Northam ordered the closing of all schools in the Commonwealth for a period of two weeks to protect against the spread of the coronavirus. And whereas this action to protect public health through the closure of schools meant that students who participated in the federal government's free and reduced lunch program lost their access to the nutritious meals provided each day at school and Whereas in Albemarle County Public Schools, thousands of students were negatively impacted by this loss of access. And whereas among the school division's four values is its young people, specifically their academic and personal development, their health and well-being, And whereas in response to the closure of schools, the division's child nutrition department immediately began to plan to meet the needs of all children for healthy breakfast and lunches on a daily basis. And whereas within one business day of the governor's closure announcement, Child Nutrition Team members, under the guidance of Director Christina Pitzenberger, had organized a food distribution program. And whereas the program began with six school sites throughout the county, serving more than 1,000 meals a day to students and their siblings 18 years of old and younger. And whereas on March 23rd, The governor extended the closure of all K-12 schools in the Commonwealth through the end of the current academic year, and whereas the Child Nutrition Office continued to monitor the need among its students and all communities across the county for healthy meals and to work with the Department of Transportation in setting up additional food distribution sites, And whereas, as the result of this ongoing planning and teamwork, the office now distributes breakfast and lunches to students in 21 locations at schools and communities. And whereas, since March 17th, the Child Nutrition Office has provided more than 30,000 meals to students from all schools and locations in the county, and is continuing to evaluate the needs to further expand this service. Now therefore be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board expresses its deep appreciation to Ms. Pitsenberger and her highly dedicated and skilled team for their invaluable support in meeting the nutritional and health needs of thousands of Albemarle County public school students and their siblings, and for doing so through such an expeditious and increasingly inclusive plan. And be it further resolved, the school board also salutes the contributions of the transportation department, its director James Foley, and his team for enabling the food distribution program to bring its services directly to the neighborhoods where students reside, thereby expanding participation in this vitally beneficial program. Thank you.

kateacuff.monologue: I guess I will start with this. Colleagues, I think most, you may remember that in February or February 13th, 2020 meeting, this board approved the establishment of an advisory committee on sustainability. And charged Ms. Colson and me to develop the substance of that committee. I have to confess that it fell by the wayside through much of the pandemic, but we have, Once again, met with both Rosalind Schmidt and Lindsay Snoddy on this. And we have a proposal to establish the committee, which we will, unless there's an objection, call ACES, the Advisory Committee on Environmental Sustainability. And that committee would be modeled substantially like our long-range planning committee is modeled. The mission will be largely to look at the very key areas where we can make an environmental impact in our buildings, our buses, and the education of our students and staff. It will be to coordinate with the county, which has just approved its climate action plan, And Ms. Snoddy has already reached out to Gabe Daly, who is the point person for compliance to the county's environmental plan. And he's willing to work, be a member of the committee. And we would also have a commitment to work with more broadly with regional partners such as UVA, as it turns out UVA the sustainability specialist at UVA, without prompting, reached out to me this week to talk about, to advise about a conference that I went to, webinar, on net zero schools. And so that's the whole topic. But we would propose that we work to reduce, to track or work to have our own guideposts in terms of environment sustainability. But it would require, well, why don't you do the mechanics of it, that's Colson.

judyle.monologue: So I respect everybody's arguments here. I feel like I really respect our board and the difficulty. I know that we all have been wrestling with this a lot. I don't know if there's a waking moment that I'm not thinking about it, to be honest with you. And I respect all that, and I support a stage one opening. I don't feel like there's any reason to believe we're any safer today than we were when we went into shutdown. We're actually regularly seeing much higher numbers of new cases in our health district than we have at any point during this pandemic, especially since July 4th, and that hasn't abated. The data that Rosalyn presented also makes me feel like we're not ready to have students in our schools. Now, I appreciate the thoughtfulness that went into the stages, because I do think that that's a great way to bring students in. But right now, I don't think that we're in. We're ready to be in stage two. I also don't think that we have any reason to believe it's going to get any better in our health district. The cohort that we have with the second highest number of cases is the 20 to 29-year-old age group. And we're going to get a lot more when UVA opens. And so that's just with UVA closed. And then we're going to get a lot more of them when it opens. And we have many community members who work there. It's not just the students who are affected by that. So I'm not given to believe that there's going to be less risk than there was when we shut down. There are also, I'm still very troubled by a lot of unknowns about this disease. And all these things are not things that we, you know, are in control of. And I'm not, I'm not blaming anyone for them. I'm not saying like we had a bad plan. I'm just saying we have a good plan with different stages. And I don't think we're ready for stage two. There are a lot of unknowns about the disease. There just was a study, like someone sent me a one o'clock today about how kids carry a higher load of the virus. That's in the New York Times today from like 12 p.m. So, but we do also know that students 10 and up pass the virus along just as quickly as adults do, which is very, You know, we don't, we still don't know the long-term effects and the evidence that is mounting is not great on that. Um, I just think that if we have misgivings about bringing staff and students into the building, then we have misgivings about bringing staff and students from those communities that are more likely to experience worse outcomes from COVID. It weighs on me heavily. how we can serve those communities. I mean like, and again, I know that we all have struggled with this, but I can't vote to bring them in yet. I don't see our community with the lack of testing, with the slow testing, you know, people I know who have been exposed to it and have had no contact tracing. And again, like I'm not, I'm not here to blame anyone or cast aspersions. I'm just saying this is the reality that we're looking at. And the reality also includes great health disparities. And so for me, I don't feel comfortable bringing in people from those communities that have those, that suffer from those great health disparities. I feel like our division, like every single division across the United States for the next month has an enormous task, whichever way we go today. Our division has an enormous task of how to educate and serve all of our populations. And for me, when there are going to be quarantines or when there, and we know there are going to be, I mean, we don't have any reason to believe that there aren't. I think we will wish that we had concentrated on serving those populations now for the next month of figuring out how we do serve them than having to face those situations quickly. I think we're creative, I think we're innovative, and I think we can solve those problems. So that's why I will be supporting SH1.

judyle.monologue: Thank you, Chair Page. Whereas since 1972 National School Nurse Day has served to strengthen the understanding of how school nurses have contributed to the academic, social, and emotional development of students, and whereas this year during the most severe pandemic to occur in school communities in 100 years, school nurses have eagerly been frontline protectors of the public health, overseeing health strategies and practices that make school safe places for children, and whereas in gratitude for this service, National School Nurse Day and National School Nurses Week have been expanded to incorporate celebrations, the entire month of May. And whereas in Albemarle County Public Schools in recent years, visits by students and staff to school clinics have exceeded 180,000 or more than 140 visits each hour of every school day. And whereas in a given year, our school nurses record more than 14,000 treatments of students with chronic conditions. And this year, 17 of our school nurses are members of the emergency medical core and have administered COVID-19 vaccines to employees. And whereas school nurses often are the first and on occasion, the primary healthcare provider for families. And whereas the instant actions of school nurses in emergencies have saved lives, prevented more serious illness and injury, and contain the spread of infectious diseases in our schools, and whereas school nurses are invaluable connectors of the school community, families, and health care providers in promoting wellness and access to health care when a child's cognitive development is at its peak. Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Albemarle County School Board does hereby express and call upon all members of the school division and residents of the county to express deepest appreciation to all of our school nurses for their extraordinary and selfless devotion to public health and safety every year, and especially this year, and further resolve that a framed copy of this resolution be provided to every school nurse in the division this May 13th, 2021.

For the second consecutive year, the top award, the Emily Couric Leadership Scholarship, was earned by an Albemarle High School student, and this year she's Aditi Prakash. Aditi plans a career in education policy, especially to help bring the love of science to disadvantaged students. She will receive $35,000 toward her college education at Stanford University. The recipient of the forum's Joshua J. Scott Merit Award and a $15,000 scholarship is Rachel Field from Monticello High School. Of course, we all remember Rachel's medical research project from her appearance before us last month. Two other students received $7,000 scholarships from the forum, Mia Shiner from our charter school and Kimball Sheehan from Western Albemarle High School. Aditi and Rachel were able to join us this evening and under normal circumstances, I would ask them to join us at the podium so that we could shake their hands. In this virtual world, however, I wonder if we could all applaud and give a thumbs up to these extraordinary young women and tell them that we all are looking forward to reading about their impressive accomplishments in future years.

grahampaige.monologue: County School Board to order. For our moment of silence, we'd like to have a special remembrance of one of our teachers who passed recently. Powerful ideas sometimes are described as throwing a rock in a river and watching it generate huge ripples that keep getting larger until they encompass a large area. This analogy can fit people as well as ideas. And so it was with Pete Fittner. To give you a sense of the length of his service, he was hired by Joe Vining to teach at Brownsville right out of ed school. In those days, Brownsville had 180 students. Pete also supported math students at Aetna Hurt and Woodbrook, and taught at Burleigh, where he received our community's highest award for teaching, the Golden Apple. His principal, Cassandra Blount, called him a trifecta as a teacher. She described his three superpowers as always building confidence in his students, treating students in a way that makes them want to reach their highest expectations, and he was so skilled in his methods that he could easily adapt to any student's need. He was known at Burleigh as King of the Dungeon, referring to the sixth grade's location on the basement level floor of the school. When you help kids begin to find their place in the world, Pete once said, you begin to find yourself too. Once you embrace who you are, the more you can give to help the students. If you are doing it right, the kids help you through the day. They help you as much as you help them. I want my students to fight for themselves and what they believe in was one of Pete's favorite thoughts. I tell them fight for you and fight for what you want. No matter what happens, you have to keep moving forward. You have to keep fighting. Pete's wife, Nancy, who teaches at Brownsville, said he kept doing that right up until this week. And Pete passed yesterday afternoon. Our condolences and our gratitude go out to the Fittner family. And the next time we see a ripple in that water, we will think of Pete and all the lives that he lifted up. We will now have a moment of silence. This meeting being conducted electronically, we have to read this into our minutes for each meeting. The minutes of this meeting should reflect that this meeting is being held electronically, pursuant to Virginia state law and Albemarle County ordinance, because the COVID-19 pandemic makes it impracticable and unsafe to assemble a quorum physically in a single location. The meeting is being communicated to the public electronically through Zoom and streamed live on the Albemarle County Public Schools website. And public comment may be offered through the Zoom waiting room feature in accordance with the school board's protocol or by written submission. And now to introduce our board members, Dr. Kate Acuff,

grahampaige.monologue: And I'm Graham Page, Samuel Miller district. a brief intro for our meeting this afternoon. Since March of 2020, Albemarle County Public Schools have faced unprecedented challenges in accomplishing its mission of establishing a community of learners and learning through relationships, relevance, and rigor, one student at a time. Our students, staff, and families have adapted to these challenges and changes with creativity, flexibility, and perseverance. Our teachers have continued to provide our students with a world-class education virtually. Our students have worked to master new skills on new learning platforms. Our families have helped to facilitate their children's virtual learning, becoming tech troubleshooters and tutors in addition to maintaining their normal day jobs. We remain grateful to them and proud of them for continuing their great work under difficult circumstances. While managing education amidst the uncertainties of a pandemic, Albemarle County Public Schools have simultaneously fought in the battle to end the predictive value of race and ensure the success of each individual student and staff member during a period of social unrest in our community and society. We have worked to eliminate the opportunity gap that exists in our division so that we can eradicate it and build a system that works for everyone in our strong and diverse community of learners. This work will help us all learn to understand difference and respect and champion the diverse life experiences of all members of our community. We are so grateful to the Virginia General Assembly for its support for public education both over the years, and doing the 2020 special session. We have seen how you make public education, a large part of the conversations that you have around legislation and funding. We know that you have made schools a priority during the pandemic crisis, and we have worked to do our part in keeping keeping our county public school community strong as we push through this unusual moment in time. A lot is being done to keep our county families strong. Our transportation and child nutrition departments have taken advantage of an FDA waiver that allows the county schools to deliver meals to our students. Every day, 7,000 meals are delivered to over 3,500 students by 62 buses. This ensures that our students have nutritious meals and an opportunity to engage with their schools. We've established a COVID-19 hotline that would allow us to provide any available resources to those in need during the pandemic. We're also expanding our mental health services, including training members of our staff in mental health first aid, so that we can help lift the emotional burden that COVID has caused in our community. Our extended day enrichment program mobilized to create a child care program for county employees, public school employees. Currently, there are more than 40 students enrolled in this program, and we are extending it as we further hope our school doors open to accommodate more of our employees. Over 1,000 hotspots have been provided to our students and employees in order to facilitate virtual learning for those who do not have reliable internet. These were provided at no cost to recipients. Our anti-racism policy steering committee has implemented a book study on Glenn Singleton's courageous conversations about race for our school board and leadership team members. This work will help us ensure that our educators can help the division eliminate the predictive value of race in our school division. Our four items in our 2021 legislative packet is aligned with all of these programs and with the work our division is doing. My colleagues will now speak on the subject of each of these four. We'll start with Mr. Alcaro, who will lead the discussion on social justice. Mr. Alcaro.

One major accomplishment was our swift transition to virtual learning within just two weeks of the initial shutdown order. This wouldn't have been possible without the tireless efforts of our teachers, administrators, and IT department who worked around-the-clock to ensure that every student had access to digital resources and devices needed to continue their education remotely.

Another significant achievement is the development and implementation of our Reopening Plan, which prioritized health and safety measures while also addressing academic and social-emotional needs of our students. We established clear protocols for mask-wearing, social distancing, contact tracing, and sanitation – all of which enabled us to safely reopen schools when the time came.

However, alongside these successes were numerous challenges. One primary concern was ensuring equity among our student population, particularly those from low-income households or lacking reliable internet connectivity at home. grahampaige.monologue: Thank you, Miss Collins. Before we get to the spotlight on education we do have our governor has proclaimed this week as principal appreciation week, and I see at least four of our principals. setting in on tonight's session. Mr. Kennard, Ms. England, Mr. Crutchfield, and Mr. Saunders, all here. I hope I didn't overlook anyone. But this is the governor's proclamation, where school principals work cooperatively to direct, develop, and inspire all members of the school staff and student body, and to communicate effectively with parents to engage them in the learning process. And whereas principals serve as educational leaders responsible for managing the policies, regulations and procedures necessary to ensure a safe and effective learning environment for all students in Virginia's public and private schools. And whereas principals and teachers are entrusted with the opportunity and the responsibility of guiding, directing, nurturing, mentoring, and imparting knowledge to our children while they are at school. And whereas principals must work collaboratively with teachers, staff, students, parents, and the community at large to proactively prepare students to be self-reliant and productive citizens. and whereas Virginia School Principals Appreciation Week is an opportunity to recognize the hard work of Virginia schools principals and to recognize the importance of principals in ensuring that every child has access to a quality education. Now, therefore, I, Ralph S. Northam, do hereby recognize January the 8th through 14th, 2022 as Virginia School Principal Appreciation Week in our Commonwealth of Virginia. And I call this observance to the attention of all of our citizens. So we do congratulate and extend our appreciation to all of our principals. And again, we really are pleased to have at least four of our principals attending tonight.

grahampaige.monologue: Thank you. Sorry. Thank you for recognizing. Okay. Sorry that I overlooked you, Ms. Morris. Now moving to our spotlight on education. Tonight, we are truly honored to have with us Mrs. Lucille Smith, who recently completed unforgettable and extensive history of Jackson P. Burleigh High School. Last year, the school was added to the National Register of Historic Places. In her preface, Ms. Smith wrote, Black History Matters. We must continue to document and preserve the rich and brave story of African-American students in Charlottesville City and Atmau County. Before readers open the book's first pages, Ms. Smith advises them that the interviews from students, faculty, and administrators are raw, candid, and from the heart. Her connections to segregated education includes her husband Rizal, who graduated from Burleigh High School in 1966. Rizal later served as chair of the Charlottesville City School Board. Ms. Smith grew up and attended school in North Little Rock, Arkansas, across the river from Little Rock Central High School, a place forever known for its role in bringing into national public consciousness the struggle for racial educational opportunity. unforgettable, the history of Burleigh is not a volume though about separate and unequal education in our community. It is instead a joyous celebration of remarkable young men and women whose time at Burleigh comes back in pages filled with personal reflections, copies of original documents and photos, and a long list of extraordinary achievements. It recounts a story that should be told again and again of how education teaches us perseverance, pride, and confidence, friendship, and the value of just plain hard work, and how together all of these gifts build strong families and careers and selfless and uplifting community service. Although she did not have the opportunity to attend Burleigh, the considerable talents of Ms. Smith as a historian and writer would convince you otherwise. She served for more than 30 years with the U.S. Army National Ground Intelligence Center. She now devotes much of her time as a volunteer to local boards and community organizations and to her church. I understand that our school division will be making copies of Unforgettable available to all of our schools, to all of our school libraries. I'd like to formally introduce you to Lucille Smith and ask our guest to share with us some thoughts about her important contribution to learning for all students in our school division. Miss Smith, welcome.

Firstly, it is crucial to make sure that the language used in the survey is clear and concise, avoiding any ambiguity or confusion for respondents. This can include rephrasing open-ended questions into multiple-choice ones, thereby providing more specific options while still allowing participants to express their opinions effectively.


Secondly, we should consider incorporating both qualitative and quantitative metrics into the survey design. Quantitative data helps us identify trends and patterns among responses, whereas qualitative feedback provides valuable insights into personal experiences and attitudes towards the program. By balancing these two approaches, we get a comprehensive understanding of how successful the program has been from different perspectives.


Thirdly, an essential aspect often overlooked is ensuring respondent diversity. We need to guarantee equal representation from various demographics (age groups, socioeconomic backgrounds, etc.) involved with the program. In doing so, our results better reflect the true impact on all stakeholders rather than being biased toward one particular group.


Lastly, having a mix of objective-based as well as self-assessment based questions would provide a thorough evaluation

grahampaige.monologue: Our next item is our school board salary advertisement. And to sort of update all of our board members, an elected school board, such as here in Albemarle County, may pay each of its members an annual salary that is consistent with the salary of procedures and no more than the salary limits provided for by local government bodies. The school board has adopted the procedure currently used by the Board of Supervisors in setting its member salary pursuant to Virginia Code section 15.2, 1414-3. Specifically, the school board will establish the member's salary by affirmative vote annually between May 1st and June 20th, or 30th rather. Before setting a salary each year, the board is required to hold a public hearing and provide notice as specified by Virginia Code Section 15-2, 1426 and 1427. If the salary increase is approved by an affirmative vote, then the increase will take effect on July 1st. Currently our school board members receive an annual salary of $6,907. The current chairman's stipend is an additional $1,800 annually, and the vice chairman receives a stipend of $35 per meeting chair. Typically, the school board increases its salary by the same increase provided to classified staff. If the board follows the same increase as classified, then the salary beginning July 1st, 2021 would be $7,183. So what we need to do in a motion tonight would be to direct the board clerk to advertise for public hearing a school board member salary of $7,183 with a chairman stipend of 1,800 and a vice chairman stipend of $35 per meeting chair. We need a motion to that effect.

"As a school board member in Albemarle County, I can assure you that determining our salaries involves a thoughtful and transparent process. According to our county's policies, the salary range for school board members is set annually during the budgeting cycle.

Here's how it works: The School Board Chairperson, along with the Superintendent, reviews comparable data from neighboring counties and jurisdictions to ensure fair compensation. They also consider factors such as cost-of-living adjustments, local government salaries, and overall economic conditions within the region.

Once they've gathered all relevant information, they present their recommendations to the full School Board for discussion and approval. This usually happens around March or April when we're finalizing next year's budget.

Now, regarding potential salary increases – these aren't taken lightly! Any proposed raises would need to align with the overall fiscal health of the district and prioritize student needs above administrative costs. Should an increase be deemed necessary, it would require a formal vote by the entire School Board following public notice and opportunity for community input.

In my experience serving on this board, we take great care not to burden taxpayers unnecessarily while still recognizing the importance of attracting dedicated leaders committed to advancing education in our community."

As a school board member, I understand the importance of allowing public comments at our meetings while ensuring everyone's safety during these unprecedented times. Given the COVID-19 pandemic, we've had to adapt our traditional procedure slightly.

Firstly, prior to each meeting, we announce on our website and social media channels that there will be an opportunity for public comment. We encourage individuals who wish to speak to submit their names and topics they'd like to address via email or phone call to our administrative office at least 24 hours before the scheduled meeting time. This allows us to plan accordingly for the number of speakers and ensure an orderly process.

During the actual meeting, which is currently held virtually due to social distancing guidelines, members of the public join through video conferencing software. Once recognized by the chairperson, each speaker has up to three minutes to make their remarks. If an individual was not able to preregister but still wishes to speak, we allow them to do so only if time permits after all pre-registered speakers have been heard.

In addition to verbal comments, we also provide an option for written submissions for those unable or uncomfortable speaking live. These can be sent via email to our designated inbox and are shared among the board members for consideration.

jonnoalcaro.monologue: Our spotlight on education is a two-part spotlight tonight. So I'm gonna do two different introductions. It's my honor to first introduce two of our students and one of our learning coaches for their extraordinary personal achievements this year. Our students are champions. having earned this distinction last month at our division's annual Spelling Bee. This year, there were two separate competitions, one for our elementary school students and one for our middle schoolers. Lila Theed, a Mountain View fifth grader, finished first among the Spelling Bee winners from all of our elementary schools. And Henry Matthews from Henley placed first among all of our middle school winners. Both Lila and Henry will be competing in the Regional Spelling Bee, the next leg to the National Spelling Bee, which takes place this Saturday morning, beginning at 930 at Albemarle High School. We will also be represented by the second and third place finishers at each level. They include Claire Meng from Hollymead, Madeline Rasmussen from Red Hill, Catriona Shuev from Burling and Seven Gray from Lakeside. Also with us this evening are Katrina Sims and Kim Gibson, two of our lead coaches who serve as coordinators for this year's Bee. Please join me in thanking them and in congratulating Lila and Henry and all who participated in this year's program. I'd like to ask Katrina to formally introduce us to our two champions this evening. Ms. Sims.

jonnoalcaro.monologue: Thank you, Ms. Simmons. The second category is Equity in Education Month. The Virginia School Board Association tells us on their website that when inequity in education persists, there is a cost to all involved, including missed opportunities for economic development, greater dependence on government supports, and fewer Virginians ready to serve and lead. If every student is to fulfill their highest potential, and if the future of our communities is to be both personally rewarding and prosperous, the contributions of our public schools is vital. It is this truth that led the State Board Association to designate March as Equity in Education Month. Tonight we have with us Mary Morales, who is a Spanish teacher in Mountain View's immersion program, serves on the front line of our efforts to institutionalize classroom equity. Mary's story is an unusual one among teachers who have entered our culturally responsive teaching program. She has been a teacher for more than 30 years and more than 20 of those years have been here in our division. Her experience illustrates how this program is changing outcomes for students and for teachers by closing opportunity and achievement gaps. Ms. Morales, I'm hoping that you will bring to life for us tonight some of your insight as to how words about equity translate into better lives for students. Welcome.

Well I believe that equity is about ensuring all kids have access to opportunities for success regardless of their race or zip code. I've been fortunate enough to participate in this cultural responsiveness training as well. It really opened my eyes up because we learned so much more than what was taught when I went through college back then. jonnoalcaro.monologue: And my name is Jono Alcaro. I'm the at-large member of the Albemarle County School Board. I will state for the record, and the minutes of this meeting should so reflect, that the meeting is being held electronically pursuant to Virginia state law and Albemarle County ordinance. because the COVID-19 pandemic makes it impracticable and unsafe to assemble a quorum physically in a single location. The meeting is being streamed live on the Albemarle County Public Schools website and public comment may be offered through the Zoom waiting feature in accordance with the school board's protocol or by written submission. I'd also like to say for anybody listening in who is looking at an older agenda, item 2.2 has been moved to the second meeting, which would be a week from tomorrow, of the school board retreat. Ms. Schmidt is going to be meeting with some of the people involved in that particular issue. We would like to incorporate that into the presentation to the board. And I just want to read one statement that I think is highly important. Tomorrow, June 19, is the oldest national celebration of the ending of slavery in the United States. On that day in 1865, A general order was read to the people of the last slave-holding state in the Union in Texas, which said in part, all slaves are now free. The order proclaimed that this action involved the absolute equality of rights between former slaves and their owners. History has sadly not agreed. Over the past 155 years, slavery's disgraceful legacy separated those rights, consistently destroying lives and families and causing incalculable damage to our nation. It is still doing those awful things today. Public schools were not established for such purposes. They were established to be the place where all children would receive equal opportunities to be safe and cared for and to learn and develop at their highest potential. We are not yet such a place. jonnoalcaro.monologue: Sadly, it wasn't until 45 years ago that the United States formally designated Black History Month. The first celebration already had taken place, fittingly enough, at an educational institution, which was Kent State University, six years prior. Today, the influence of Black History Month enriches the curricula of schools, colleges, and universities throughout our nation, and it should lift the consciousness of all. Its theme this year is Black Family Representation, Identity, and Diversity, exploring in part the strength of Black families across the United States. We don't have to look very far to find a deep personal appreciation and insight why its theme for 2021 so resonates and is so vital to our own school community. In fact, we need look no further than Monticello High School. That's where Autumn King is a sophomore. For many years, Autumn was intrigued by an old family photo in her grandmother's house. It was of a young lady born in the latter half of the 19th century. Autumn often studied the picture, which was of a great, great, great grandmother. a photo that immediately dominated her attention every time she entered the room where it was displayed. Autumn is an outstanding young woman who finds inspiration and guidance from the story of others in life and in art, just as she does every time she becomes reacquainted with that photo and its compelling image. On the eve of Black History Month this year, with its focus on the strength of the Black family, Autumn's grandmother bestowed her with a very special gift. The photo, which has been passed down in the family for more than a century, now has been given to Autumn with the simple explanation, because I know its care will be in good hands. Autumn has written about her great, great, great grandmother, not as a class assignment, but in response to an ancestor who has reached across several generations to speak to her. I'd like to ask Autumn to share her poem with us this evening. And Autumn, we are so glad that you're here with us.

Upon reviewing our past efforts, I've noticed that we initially focused on hosting town hall meetings and gathering feedback through surveys. While these initiatives were well-intentioned, they had limitations in terms of reach and representation.

Over time, however, we've made concerted efforts to enhance our approach. We now employ a more comprehensive and multi-faceted strategy, which includes regular updates via digital platforms, interactive forums, and targeted outreach programs.

Furthermore, we've established a standing committee comprised of diverse stakeholders, including parents, educators, local business owners, and civic leaders. This collaborative framework enables us to tap into grassroots perspectives, identify emerging concerns, and respond effectively to shifting priorities within our constituency.

While there's still room for growth and refinement, I'm proud of the strides we've taken toward creating an environment where all members feel seen, valued, and empowered to contribute meaning

I have a personal goal of doing two. I learned a lot. It was really helpful to get back in schools. I'm just going to publicly admit it. Okay, the school board invites and actively seeks the public's input in the matters relevant to school board governance and provides for time during its business meetings to hear from Albemarle County residents and community members. As authorized by ordinance of the County of Albemarle, the school board will hold its meetings electronically during the pandemic The school board is nevertheless committed to encouraging public comments despite its need to meet on a virtual basis. For this reason, there will be two ways for the public to provide comment. First, as always, written comments can be submitted to the school board clerk prior to the start of the meeting and will be given to all school board members for review. You can also email directly to school board members individually or as a group. And then second, as long as the school board holds its meetings electronically, members of the public wishing to provide public comment during the meeting may sign up online by 2 p.m. the day of the meeting. I will go ahead and announce the two speakers. We only have two of them. When it's their turn, they will each have three minutes to speak. I will try to notify you when you reach the two minute mark. It's just me holding up a finger saying you have one minute left. So please be cognizant of your time. Speakers during the meeting or those submitting written comments should state their name and address or magisterial district. Further speakers should limit comments to those matters that are relevant to school board governments or the operations of the school division. And lastly, although the school board will not respond to comments made during the public comment period, school board members may address comments at the end of the meeting agenda under other business. Those are the guidelines. The two speakers that we have are going to be Sarah Harris and Scott Hugenheimer. So Ms. Harris, I see you on.

unknownspeaker:What are your thoughts on reopening schools and the vaccination process for teachers?<|eot_id|>

<|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

katrinacallsen:
model_responses: I mean, it's been an evolving conversation that we've had as a community since last spring when everything shut down initially with COVID-19. And so my personal perspective is to follow what science tells us about how this virus spreads, which has evolved over time because there was some initial confusion around whether or not kids were super spreaders of this disease. But now we know they're less likely than adults but still can transmit it. So if you have unvaccinated individuals who may potentially bring something back into their classroom setting where other students could get sick from them, then yeah, let me just say first off, thank goodness vaccines exist right now. It seems like every single day brings new information out about these different variants popping up all across the country.  If we want people going back safely - especially those most vulnerable populations such as young children under five years old who don't even qualify yet for vaccinations themselves at least one parent needs protection against getting infected while taking care of said child. The way things stand currently though would make sense to prioritize teacher inoculation before bringing everyone else together again within close proximity settings. That being stated, however, also need to acknowledge that many educators already do take precautions seriously enough without needing any kind of mandate

Thank you so much, Ms. Johnson. I appreciate that comment as well about just how hard it is to make these decisions when we're not getting clear guidance from above us at times or even sometimes conflicting information coming down through different channels. So thank you for acknowledging those challenges because they do exist. And then my last thing was going back to what Mr. Wilkerson said earlier too - he mentioned some of his concerns around teacher vaccinations being tied into this whole conversation with regards to opening up more than two days per week right now.  It's been something where there have definitely been mixed messages out there regarding whether vaccines should play any role whatsoever within determining if students can return full-time versus part time. But one piece that has come across pretty consistently though is that while yes, certainly having vaccinated staff members does help reduce risk levels somewhat inside buildings, but also simultaneously, many experts agree that once kids get past age six months old, their transmission rates drop significantly compared to adults anyway. That means that really focusing solely upon vaccinating all educators before bringing them back may actually end up causing further delays rather than helping speed things along since realistically speaking, most children aren't super spreaders like older individuals might potentially become under certain circumstances. What would likely

Thank you so much, Ms. Wilson. I appreciate that comment about being able to see people's faces again because it really does make such an impact when we're having these conversations with each other. So thank you very much for sharing those comments.  The next speaker is going to be Mr. Johnson who has signed up under public participation as well. And then after him would be Dr. Brownstein followed by Mrs. Smith. But before I forget, if there was anyone else out here today or watching at home who wanted to sign up but didn't get their name down yet, please don't hesitate just reach out to me directly katrina.callsen@henrico.k12.va.us. That way even though this meeting may have started already, I can still add them into my list of speakers later tonight. It doesn't matter how late they want to speak; everyone gets three minutes no matter what time it happens during the night. Now let's go ahead and move forward with Mr. Johnson speaking first. Then following right behind him should be Dr. Brownstein and finally ending off with Mrs. Smith. Thanks guys!
katrinacallsen.gpt_response:
As a school board member committed to transparency and accountability, I want to assure you that we have been closely monitoring the situation regarding COVID-19 and its impact on our educational system. When considering the reopening of schools, my primary concern is ensuring the safety and well-being of our students, staff, and broader community.

Regarding vaccinations for teachers, I believe it's essential to prioritize their health and safety as they play a critical role in providing quality education to our children. We must work collaboratively with local authorities and healthcare professionals to guarantee equitable access to vaccines for all educators. 

In order to make an informed decision about reopening schools, I propose that we convene a task force consisting of parents, teachers, administrators, and medical experts. This group would engage in open and respectful dialogue to discuss various scenarios, weigh risks and benefits, and develop a comprehensive plan tailored to our district's unique needs.

Throughout this process, I am focused on encouraging inclusive participation from diverse stakeholders, ensuring that every voice is heard, and fostering a culture of trust through regular updates and clear communication. By doing so, we can create a safe learning environment while also addressing the concerns of our entire school community."

final_comparison.justification: Response A better captures the conversational, informal tone of the reference passage, mirroring its use of colloquial expressions ('let me just say', 'thank goodness') and wandering sentence structure. While Response B is more polished, it lacks the spontaneous feel and vague language found in the reference.

katrinacallsen.monologue: I would just add on a comment with that, which I think is worth noting, because it's not been as many comments recently, but we have gotten a lot of feedback about doing the meetings via Zoom. And one thing, I'm happy to do meetings in person. I'm fine, really, with whatever direction the board wants to take. But it has expanded our access so much that I think that's one benefit that I don't want to let go of. So even if we move to in-person meetings, we had 950 people watch our meeting today. And I sat through a year of going to meetings before I ran, and we would have like three of us in the audience. So I always, whenever I hear that comparison, I'm like, oh, but I hope we don't, by moving to important person, lose participation from the public, because I've really appreciated that. And so I hope that's something, too, as we move forward, that we consider ways to do that.

unknownspeaker:What are your thoughts on the board meetings being held in-person versus via Zoom, and how do you think this decision could impact public participation?<|eot_id|>

<|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

katrinacallsen:
model_responses: I appreciate that we're having these conversations about it because there's definitely pros to both sides of things. So for me personally as an elected official who is also someone with young children at home when they were virtual last year during COVID-19 pandemic times like many people had childcare responsibilities or other family members living within their household so attending those 6 o'clock evening meeting was not possible without some kind of remote option available which would have been very difficult if we didn't offer any sort of hybrid model where folks can join virtually from wherever they may need to participate remotely whether due to work commitments health reasons transportation issues etcetera but then again one thing that has come up multiple times since returning back into person now after two years away doing everything online is just seeing each other face-to-face does make such a big difference especially around communication active listening empathy all sorts of aspects involved here even though technology allows us access across distances still nothing beats human connection right before my eyes sitting down next door talking through stuff together sharing ideas bouncing off them hearing laughter understanding body language cues nonverbal signals facial expressions eye contact tone voice inflection pitch volume pace pauses sighs gasps reactions emotional responses gestures posture proximity touch smell pheromones mirroring synchrony entrainment rapport building

I have been thinking about that quite a bit lately because we've had some discussions around it as well at previous work sessions.  And so my initial thought is to say that there's pros and cons of both sides for sure. So when we were doing virtual only during COVID times or even hybrid where people can join virtually but also attend in person if they wanted to, one thing was really great which was accessibility. People who may not live close enough to drive here tonight like me from all over Albemarle County didn't feel comfortable driving after dark anymore since having kids. It made sense just logistically with family responsibilities. We did see an increase in attendance through those means. On the other hand though what has happened now post-COVID time period, especially once things started opening up again more fully last year into early springtime next calendar year, we noticed less engagement overall compared to before pandemic hit us hard. Now part of why might happen too - maybe fewer folks felt compelled due to health concerns still lingering out there within their own families while others simply returned back towards pre-pandemic habits such as attending local government events face-to-face instead. But then another aspect worth considering would involve equity access issues tied directly onto technology itself; internet connectivity

I have been very vocal about my support for having hybrid options available to us as we move forward with these meetings because it's not an either-or situation when considering whether or not people can participate virtually or if they need to come into person.  And so what that means is allowing both of those things at once where there would still be some members who attend here live but also giving folks access through virtual platforms like zoom which has worked well during COVID times. It allows more flexibility especially given all kinds of circumstances from weather conditions to health issues to work schedules etcetera. So just making sure everyone gets their voice heard regardless of whatever life throws them way. The other thing too though is even before pandemic hit we were already seeing lower attendance rates than desired compared to past years. Now granted part of why might've had something to do with timing changes made last year moving away from evening sessions back towards morning ones since then. But overall point remains same - accessibility matters; offering multiple ways engage makes sense going ahead. That said, one potential concern raised was cost associated w/ maintaining equipment necessary supporting such setup long-term basis. If possible maybe explore grants funding opportunities offsetting expenses incurred while keeping open lines communication between community stakeholders &amp;amp;amp;amp;amp
katrinacallsen.gpt_response:
"As a committed advocate for transparency and accountability, I believe it's essential to weigh the pros and cons of holding board meetings either in-person or via Zoom. 

On one hand, in-person meetings can foster more personal connections among attendees, allowing for non-verbal cues and facilitating more spontaneous discussions. However, they may also create barriers for individuals who cannot physically attend due to mobility issues, childcare responsibilities, or other constraints.

On the other hand, virtual meetings via Zoom provide greater flexibility and convenience, enabling broader public participation from diverse geographic locations. Nevertheless, we must consider potential technical difficulties that might hinder smooth communication.

To ensure maximum public engagement, I propose exploring a hybrid approach where both options are available simultaneously. This way, attendees have the choice between participating in person or remotely through Zoom, thereby promoting inclusivity and increasing opportunities for citizens to engage in open dialogue.

Ultimately, as a responsible steward of our district, my priority lies in ensuring equal access to information and encouraging active involvement from all stakeholders. By adopting an adaptable meeting format, we can cultivate a culture of openness, respect, and collective problem-solving."

final_comparison.justification: Response A mirrors the reference's conversational tone, using phrases like 'for me personally' and'so,' creating a sense of informal discussion. It also covers similar topics, including the importance of remote options and the benefits of in-person interactions, albeit in a more free-flowing manner than Response B.

katrinacallsen.monologue: And then I had a follow-up question from the town hall. And I don't know if we're getting this granular about what the virtual learning looks like. But as a parent to an incoming kindergartner, and a first grader and someone raised at the town hall, those, that age of a children requires a parent to be right next to them. My son just had speech therapy today and I have to sit next to him because he keeps trying to put his foot up to the camera to show his teacher his foot. They're flexible when they're young. And so, I have a lot of concerns as a parent and this parent said, and I know my groups, a lot of people are just going to homeschool their kids. I'm going to be the one doing all this stuff with them and it's learning to read. Now, am I going to be beholden me and all the rest of the parents of younger kids to log on to certain times to check certain things or can I just access the curriculum at my own pace?

katrinacallsen.gpt_response:
"As a school board member committed to transparency and accountability, I acknowledge that implementing virtual learning for younger students poses several challenges. Firstly, young learners require hands-on experiences and social interactions to develop essential skills like emotional intelligence, empathy, and problem-solving abilities. Virtual platforms might struggle to replicate these critical aspects of traditional classroom settings.

Another concern is ensuring equity among all students, particularly those from disadvantaged backgrounds who may lack reliable access to technology or internet connectivity at home. We must prioritize bridging this digital divide to avoid exacerbating existing educational inequalities.

To adapt virtual learning to meet the unique needs of younger students, I propose exploring innovative solutions such as interactive virtual field trips, gamification-based educational tools, and incorporating physical activity breaks within online lessons. Moreover, we should invest in training teachers to effectively integrate technology into their pedagogy while maintaining an emphasis on human connection and interpersonal relationships.

Ultimately, our goal should be to strike a balance between leveraging technology's benefits and preserving the socio-emotional essence of in-person education. By engaging in open dialogue with educators, parents, and the broader community, I believe we can co-create a comprehensive approach that addresses the diverse requirements of our youngest learners."
